comments.commentBody:
I had two bouts of alopecia areata in my mid twenties, both of which occurred after identical emotional stressors. I greatly appreciate what was said in this article; finally I have confirmation as to the trigger.

I was diagnosed with lupus a few years back, and from what I have read it seems possible the disease was present but only mildly active for many years...lupus is another autoimmune disease associated with alopecia. I am not clear if they are two separate conditions or if one actually causes the other.

I agree that hair loss can be devasting when you're young and female. My first bout left me with a perfectly round bald patch the size of an egg on the upper back of my head. For many months, until it was completely grown back in (had cortisone injections), I rigorously applied a set of bobby pins to hold my remaining hair in place to cover up the spot. The second bout was a host of diffuse spots that were not noticeable without moving my hair. I consider myself lucky.

Last year I had chemo and lost every hair on my body, but at 50 (and after everything else I've been through with lupus), it wasn't so hard to deal with. I might have become a shut-in had I gone completely bald 25 years ago.

Be H+? You're Not Alone. There are over 70 million people at positiveloves com same with you. It's common to feel guilty or ashamed when you are diagnosed with h+. You may feel that your sex life is ruined or that someone you thought you could trust has hurt you. You may feel sad or upset. Keep in mind that you are one of millions of people who have it.
In all reality, Sputnik IV crashed in Manitowoc.  The Sputnik that terrorized America was the original launch.

There was another light moment in Obama's speech in reference to high speed trains when he jokingly referred to another advantage of it, namely avoiding being padded down.
But back to the fast trains, they will make sense in the busiest corridors among close lying metropolitan areas in the Northeast, Florida, Midwest, and of course California. Planes need expensive high purity fuels, and with oil prices going ever higher, the sky evermore crowded, and commuting traffic to and from airports increasingly bogged down and expensive, the financial drawbacks will rapidly be reduced and prospects for train travel enhanced in view of the convenience and hassle free environment it provides. Fuel efficient cars will help the cost aspects, but the ever increasing traffic and slowing down of new highway construction will make commuting nearly intolerable. And forget about electric cars, the first few million will be OK, but we don't have the power generation and distribution structure to accommodate the tens of million of cars needed to even make a moderate impact on our oil consumption ( I guesstimate we probably have in excess of 150 million or more cars and trucks on the US highways). And the Republican agenda will certainly not help in overcoming most of the obstacles just mentioned.

I was dismayed that Obama spoke about stopping  jobs going overseas, he spoke about keeping foreign nationals who study here,  but said nothing about jobs going to illegals in the US.  Reviewing immigration law so as to actually increase the competition for US jobs is a travesty.

The title of this article is very misleading.  First: we are not "post-war" -- we are in the middle of two wars, with hundreds of thousands of American troops in Iraq and Afghanistan.  Second:  the deficit is largely due to the money we are spending in these two wars -- $3 trillion dollars already --according to Nobel winner Joseph Stiglitz and Harvard Professor Linda Bilmes.

#27 Dan wrote: "The incessant tedium you get from conservatives about government and government spending is more than I can bear at this stage. We should replace them all with a pull string doll chirping inane tripe e.g. Amy's post #2. At least it would be fluffy and cute to go along with ignorant and annoying."

Agreed. ....maybe that's what they're going for with Bachmann and Palin? (And to be "fair and balanced" across the genders, Glenn Beck is certainly fluffy.)

I have an assignment for Sarah Palin!

She should take Michele Bachman to some Civil War battle grounds and then walk through some of the cemeteries. Gettysburg. Vicksburg. Fort Sumter. Bull Run.

I don't know why Bachman gets a pass on being so offensive. Maybe because she is so absurd?
But the Civil War was no joke. More Americans died in that war than all other american wars combined. She really should apologize to the nation for her offensive remarks.

And then there is the slavery aspect to her offensive comments. I wonder if this sort of offense is something than black people experience everyday? Our country is not perfect. We can have adult discussions about our sins.

Sarah could show some real leadership and show Michele the way.

But Republicans always cover for each other.

Obama has done well to recognize the inevitable. You cannot rest on your past laurels or achievements. Globalization has opened the flood gate and only the fittest can survive in this cruel world of economic rat race. Change is avalanching upon all of us. The ones who adjust to these changes and ready to accost them efficiently will pass the test. In order to do that you have to be adequately equipped which is what Obama has urged the fellow Americans to do. Yes, go for it and push Indians and Chinese hard so that they also brush up their own skill and knowledge and in the process enrich the world.
JP at #1:  Could not have said it better myself.

Great speech, no real or specific plan. Countries that have a single payer health plan are doing better then us, as well as those that don't outsource all their jobs abroad. Come to think of it they aren't fighting two wars in foreign countries either. Hmm...
Invest properly yes, subsidize the AFL CIO through prevailing wage, no!

How stupid? look no further than the gopers, birthers, baggers, conservatives.....I could go on....

To those above, what specfic legislation has the GOP submitted that will produce jobs? Be specific on how many jobs such legislation will produce. Auggie, Leah, TR, Royballs, Amy???? Answers / Responses?

lol...I'd rather have this: Socialist, Marxist, Kenyan born, non-birth certificate person, friend of Bill Ayers, Rev Wright, Father Flaggart, pal of terrorist, producer of Obamacare, stimulas producer, auto industry bail outer, gubmint taker believer, ultra liberal, non church attending, death panel believing, Hugo Chavez book recieving, citizen of world, U.S. apologizing, President than cheney/bush or mccain/palin duo any day......

Palin/Bachmann in 2012 - Baggers and birthers you must be heard and recognized by the GOP, don't let them mock you.....

Poster # 281 & 282: Please do not try to convince American women that  the women in Islamic cultures  have freedom!  We have seen far too many video images of women covered up ( to shield men from their nasty "temptation" _ how  sexist is that?!) and or videos of  "men only" in the streets ( are women locked up at home and forbidden to come out in public??!  too weird for Western cultures!).  Western women would be the first bulwark against  a culture that commands the covering up of a woman's "beauty," while it welcomes the suicide bombing of innocents who are often  victimized under the burkas of women suicide bombers. We consider that whole idea as totally SICK!    We burned bras in the 60's.  Hopefully, not burkas in the  2010's!
Something must be wrong with me. I go to the gym consistently and I prefer not to talk to anyone...ever.

"Every child is an artist. The problem is how to remain an artist once we grow up."
~Pablo Picasso

As a professional organizer in San Francisco who has worked with numerous parents of young prolific artists, I encounter this dilemma with some degree of frequency. In fact, it led me to summarize my recommendations to parents along with a true story about a friend with a conundrum: what to do with a "world" made by her six-year-old son. http://liberatedspaces.wordpress.com...
I see in the slide show that Eli's work has been made into a book. Eli's work deserves to be in a book. The trash is a good place for the rest.

I hate clutter, but now way am I throwing away most of my kids' artwork. I'll find a way to keep it, anyway I can.

One fun thing about young children is their still-developing language skills. My young kids say the funniest things. I ask them about the pictures they have drawn, and I write what they say verbatim on the back of the drawing. Their words, novel or strange or just strung together in odd-sounding phrases, are as precious as the drawings. One day when I'm 90 and looking thru the drawings, I'll flip them over, read those words, and remember exactly what we were doing and how those kids looked 'back then'. Priceless.
By the time the kids are in upper elementary, they stop bringing art home.  So it's the art they make at home that you have to deal with.

Let's all thank the Founding Fathers for the 1st Amendment.

I do, every time I open my web browser to read the news.
(Check my address.)

I read through this twice.
It comes off as completely self-serving.
It seems the whole point is to differentiate between the "professionals" at NYT and that smelly amateur, Assange.
Did you guys get your feelings hurt or something?

Correcting the record on WMDs in Iraq? I am sure the victims of that conflict feel assured that the NYT corrected the record. You should be embarrassed by that whole paragraph. Again, self-serving.
But it's ok because you stood up to GWB on warrantless wire-tapping, in his own office no less. Huh, I bet Assange has never been in the White House. Boy, you showed him.

Ah, Bill Keller, what a mealy-mouthed piece of writing. The NYT preaching to us once again about its high moral journalistic standards. (“I’m the first to admit that news organizations, including this one, sometimes get things wrong.”) What a laughable understatement! Do you really think we’re do dumb that we’ve so quickly forgotten how culpably wrong you were and so recently on the Weapons of Mass Destruction? How gung-ho you were on the invasion of Iraq? And ask us to forget historically all those years the NYT spent pimping for the deluded Henry Kissinger (who can forget his incriminating self-description to Oriana Fallaci as John Wayne, the sheriff facing down the bad guys all alone on Main St.) while he installed murderous military juntas from Saigon to Santiago, to El Salvador? Do you think we can forget how you so quickly sold out your own reporter Ray Bonner to the Reagan administration on the 1981 El Mozote Massaacre…the list is long, dark and venal, Mr. Keller. So c’mon, we all know you’re making a ton of money off Assange and WikiLeaks and really that’s what is all about. And in that your’re no better than Rupert Murdoch. So lay off the trashy fashion notes on Assange transformed from a “bag lady” to trendy dresser and “a kind of cult figure for the European young and leftish” (what a snide small-town put down that conveniently leaves out all the youth of North America who admire Assange.) Find some humility in your situation. And just try not to screw it up too badly this time.
P.S. Oh, yeah..and thanks for the laugh about Assange being "arrogant'". I spewed up my mouthful of coffee on that one...guess you've never bumped into one of your own reporters out there on assignment.

"a source who was elusive, manipulative and volatile (and ultimately openly hostile to The Times and The Guardian)"

Bill Keller! Let's see you or ANYBODY YOU KNOW do what wikileaks did and not be elusive. and not be manipulative. and not be hostile. what are you expecting, a saint? He's human.

Come off it. Your moment is over. You got the story. You are not bigger than the story.
